gbpservice/neutron/db/grouppolicy/group_.message: I don't have a problem with this change, but was just curious: was this due to something uncovered with the PEP changes, or was this just a formatting change from an editor?

One of the new pep8 checks fails with whitespace (including a newline) on either side of the '=' when passing keyword args. So the RHS of the kwarg assignment must either be the value, or a '(' to continue the assignment on the following line.

My coding style is to always start a multi-line arg list on an indented new line, in order to have as much rooms as possible for each line of args, so I prefer this over using a '(' to break up a single kwarg into multiple lines.

gbpservice/neutron/plugins/ml2plus/drive.message: Similar question as earlier: was this uncovered due to a PEP change? Or just formatting change from an editor?
Yes - binary operators can be at the end of a line, but not the beginning.
Wow - good catch on this. Does this mean it was looking for False in data?
I don't think this changes the behavior - its just a new pep8 check that requires using "if x not in y" instead of "if not x in y".
Was this uncovered due to PEP8? Or just preference?
A new pep8 check was complaining that the loop variable name 'net' was hiding the import on line 66.

gbpservice/neutron/services/servicechain.message: I was told not to use \ to separate lines in this repo so can we still use () then?

I agree using '\' to wrap lines is generally not recommended, and using '()' can usually avoid the need. In this case, one of the new pep8 checks requires the space before the '(', which makes the line too long, triggering a different pep8 failure. I could not figure out any way other than using '\' to resolve this. If you have a better idea, please let me know.
I was told not to use \ to separate lines in this repo so can we still use () then?
See response in the other file - same issue here.

gbpservice/neutron/tests/unit/services/g.message: I like this change, but was this uncovered due to PEP8 change, or just preference?
Yes, a new pep8 check requires assertEqual/assertGreater/... instead of assertTrue with a comparison.

Second, there is nothing tricky about this print statement that could not easily be replicated by anyone at any time. Finally, do you really want the precedent of littering source code with commented out print and/or log statements just in case someone might need them?

I'll look for those python files, and if they are not important, will delete them, and if they are, will probably just restore this file.
Yes pls remove the references as you see fit then. Thx.

tox.ini.message: Wonder why we don't specify basepython as python3.5 instead? Isn't that the direction we want to move along?

This was to match upstream neutron in stable/queens. Neutron does also have functional-python35 jobs that run with python3. But as far as I can tell, these functional jobs here do not run any meaningful tests, so I decided not to bother adding those.

I noticed that we added E731, E741, W504 & W605 into this ignore list. Does that mean they used to be passing but now we will just ignore those? Guess my real question is that if they were already passing before, why do we want to add them to the ignore list now?

In the add_rocky patch, a newer version of hacking is specified in test-requirements.txt, which in turn depends on a newer version of flake8, which apparently has added these checks. I've tested this cleanup_queens patch with the rocky versions of hacking and flake8, and all issues are fixed in this patch, but I decided that our stable/queens should use the same version of hacking as upstream neutron. Technically, we could remove those newer flake8 checks from the ignore list in stable/queens, but leaving this ignore list identical across our branches makes back-porting easier, and doesn't hurt anything.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
What did you try?
https://puppet.com/docs/puppet/latest/lang_relationships.html#reference-2122

for example, if you have a service defined, the following should trigger a notification to restart the service:
File[$::sysinv::params::sysinv_conf] ~> Service['sysinv-fpga-agent']

I tried defining a service in a new class sysinv::fpga_agent which I included from puppet-manifests/src/manifests/worker.pp.

In the service definition I had a line like this:

subscribe => File[$::sysinv::params::sysinv_conf],

I think this would be equivalent to what you suggest.

My suspicion is that it's /etc/init.d/sysinv-agent that is updating the config file rather than puppet, and so the puppet refresh event doesn't get triggered.

The systemd refresh mechanism uses inotify, so it doesn't matter who makes the change.

kibana/templates/deployment.yaml.message: what happens to the liveness probe?

If the start() method executes and touched this file, the readinessProbe would immediately succeed, and as nothing will ever remove that file, this will continue to be READY and never file - in essence removing the readinessProbe all together.

If there is an issue with long wait with ES update, perhaps we can make this more robust by using a bash/py script to better handle readiness.

You're right -  I updated this change to make the probes toggle-able. In situations where the readiness check is interrupting deployment pipelines, we can disable it. Now that 733489 is merged, I hope those situations become quite rare in the future.

requirements-frozen.txt.message:
Here you are not changing the commitid or the egg, and the updated format is not listed in this document as a valid format, as per https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/pip_install/#git.
what is the reason for this change, are you fixing an issue for deckhand install?
is this illformed or does it work like this?

This was a change automatically performed by `tox -e freeze` after comments that requirements-frozen.txt needs to also be updated.

The intent of this patch is not to change deckhand in any way, it is to ensure that requirements-direct.txt from Promenade do not conflict with Deckhand for Pegleg consumption.

Pinning packageA==1.0.0 in Deckhand but packageA==2.0.0 in Promenade causes failure to install in Pegleg.

Running make images (bionic image) locally I see this output

  Cloning https://opendev.org/airship/deckhand.git (to revision 7d2092b100bddcab77fca0acadd9fc99ba59797b) to /tmp/pip-install-itrxxxqq/Deckhand
  Running command git clone -q https://opendev.org/airship/deckhand.git /tmp/pip-install-itrxxxqq/Deckhand
  Running command git checkout -q 7d2092b100bddcab77fca0acadd9fc99ba59797b

Local test of pegleg render -> promenade generate certificates with resulting image works.

Do you want to return a partial pci_device_list in the case of an exception ?

I think we actually would since something is better than nothing, but in practice it likely won't happen.  

pci_device_list is empty while we create the pci_devs list (which is the more failure-prone part).  Then we loop over the pci_devs list to write the information to pci_device_list in a particular format, and this is much less likely to fail.

The reset should only be scoped to the host is actually reboot/reset.  Currently, it looks like this patch could run on a patch application, (which could perform an inservice restart); or a pmon recovery action.

It appears the "bug" is a missing feature. The CephFS documentation [1]  claims that kernel quotas were enforced starting with kernel version 4.17; on the ubuntu bionic based service image, the kernel version is 4.15.0-101-generic. 

So, we have two options here:
- Change the base version of the service image to Focal Fossa (we will do this anyway, soon)
- Update the kernel via an element in the manila-image-elements project

Either of these can help us get these tests out of the blacklist. 

[1] https://docs.ceph.com/docs/master/cephfs/quota/#limitations

Oh wait, there's more to the kernel reqs than just needing >4.17 :(

"Quotas are implemented in the kernel client 4.17 and higher. Quotas are supported by the userspace client (libcephfs, ceph-fuse). Linux kernel clients >= 4.17 support CephFS quotas but only on mimic+ clusters. Kernel clients (even recent versions) will fail to handle quotas on older clusters, even if they may be able to set the quotas extended attributes."

This means that we *need* to also upgrade the ceph we're testing to Nautilus. Victoria's doing that here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/676722/

So we'll have to wait for that change as well.
Gah, good catch on this one...

which operation were you thinking of alarming, exactly?

It's already planned to raise a "device firmware update in progress" alarm for the subcloud as soon as there are any pending device image updates.

Are you thinking of a separate per-host alarm?  I thought we had ruled that out.
ok, we had agreed on the subcloud level alarm
Would it be possible to cancel a device image update for a host?

You can "abort" the host-device-image-update operation.  This will not abort an in-progress device image update, but will not continue on with any other pending updates.  It will leave them pending though, not cancelled.

The typical way to cancel a specific device image update is to "remove" the image (i.e. the opposite of "apply").

If I understand the process, the user is building a customized container image that is based on the "latest" stock tripleo image (cinder-volume in this example). The steps at L68 and L86, and I assume the user will deploy the customized image using an associated ContainerImagePrepare set.

Is my understanding correct? One aspect that concerns me is it looks like the user will be responsible for rebuilding their custom image each time the underlying base image changes. Otherwise the "latest" custom image will become stale, and will fall out of sync with the rest of the "latest" images in the deployment.
I'm not sure how we can clarify in that document, but happy for suggestions in a next iteration.

> If I understand the process, the user is building a customized container image that is based on the "latest" stock tripleo image (cinder-volume in this example).

 > The steps at L68 and L86, and I

 > associated ContainerImagePrepare set.

Once pushed, yes they have to update the ContainerImagePrepare set like it's the case today without that new tooling.

 > Is my understanding correct? One aspect that concerns me is it
 > looks like the user will be responsible for rebuilding their custom
 > image each time the underlying base image changes. Otherwise the
 > "latest" custom image will become stale, and will fall out of sync
 > with the rest of the "latest" images in the deployment.

How would you see it working otherwise?

I think it's already the case now. When a third party image is created (e.g. a new layer is added); we have to rebuild the child layers otherwise they get out of sync; isn't?

The traditional (and already known) method using Docker also requires the underlying layers to be updated.

The way I see the workflow is the following:

* "tcib_from: localhost/tripleomaster/openstack-cinder-volume:latest" never changes within a major version, e.g. OSP16. Unless your deployment is using a specific tag; but I think latest should be used AFIK.
* The tripleoclient command will always be the same, it'll push the vendor image to locale storage using default tag (latest); which can be overridden.
* ContainerImagePrepare doesn't need an update if we rely on latest tag.

> I think it's already the case now. When a third party image is
 > created (e.g. a new layer is added); we have to rebuild the child
 > layers otherwise they get out of sync; isn't?

Maybe we're saying the same thing, but I'll clarify my view. Consider the common situation where a vendor's cinder driver requires a software package (typically, but not always, a vendor specific python module) that isn't automatically provided by their openstack distribution. This tcib feature is a means for users (not just the vendors) to create a cinder-volume container image that contains the missing software.

Both the cinder-volume code and the vendor's software may be periodically updated. In either situation, it will be necessary for the user to rebuild their customized container image. Agreed?

 > The way I see the workflow is the following:
 > 
 > * "tcib_from: localhost/tripleomaster/openstack-cinder-volume:latest"
 > never changes within a major version, e.g. OSP16. Unless your
 > deployment is using a specific tag; but I think latest should be
 > used AFIK.
 > * The tripleoclient command will always be the same, it'll push the
 > vendor image to locale storage using default tag (latest); which
 > can be overridden.
 > * ContainerImagePrepare doesn't need an update if we rely on latest
 > tag.

I guess my concern is more of a downstream matter, and I should have highlighted that up front. Downstream, users are responsible for configuring their ContainerImagePrepare parameter to reference the vendor's cinder-volume container image, and the vendor is expected to maintain that image and keep it up to date. The user basically just deploys something like cinder-volume-vendor:latest, and the vendor ensures their "latest" is updated whenever *any* layer changes.

If the user is building the customized cinder-volume container image, then it becomes the user's responsibility to know when something has changed (in either the vendor's software or in cinder-volume itself).

This looks cool, it seems to support any (valid) bash command. This will be real handy, especially for vendors that need to "pip install" a python module, although I expect they'll first need to execute run commands that install pip.
FTR, vendors should never pip install.

yeah, the whole interface is documented here: https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-ansible/latest/roles/role-tripleo_container_image_build.html

But most of the time they will run tcib_actions with run and do what they want in there. If they want, they can even inject a script in the image and just run it if that's simpler for them. We'll probably examples here as well I guess.
I agree, and for years we've been urging vendors to provide RPMs for their python modules. Unfortunately, convincing vendors to act on that advice is an ongoing effort.
Is the extra "dev" directory intentional, or should it match the path at L40?
